section-block.rac_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: I Am a Cat

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Galia Bernstein
section-block.rac_book_summary: Simon the house cat convinces big cats from the wild that they are all part of the same family. Although they don’t believe him at first, together they learn what makes all of them part of the cat family!

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about animals they know. Choose two animals and work with children to compare their differences and similarities.
Invite children to sing “Old MacDonald Had a Farm,” filling in the names of animals they know and showing how the animals move and sound.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein.
Scout loves all sorts of books, but he especially loves narratives like this one. They tell such interesting stories!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What are some features that cats have?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is one feature that Lion and Simon share?
What features does Tiger talk about to describe cats?
What features does Lion say all cats have?
Simon says he has all those features. How is he different from the big cats?
Simon has the same features as the other cats. Is he part of the cat family? Why or why not?
Show me a thumbs-up if you think Simon is part of the cat family or a thumbs-down if you think he is not.
section.rac_body-text: Ask 1–2 children why they put their thumbs up or down.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some features that cats have?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about animal features as children watch and listen. Then show children how they can combine two of the sentences without changing their meaning.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do cats have long tails or long ears?
Which feature do you think is most useful for cats? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning new vocabulary words is key to a preschool child’s academic preparation for kindergarten. Children’s vocabulary grows significantly when vocabulary instruction is introduced in read aloud books. Promote children’s vocabulary development by identifying suitable vocabulary for explicit instruction during story time.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Flexible Thinking
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time when children thought one thing, but then changed their minds to think something different. Ask what made them change their minds. Explain that when we show flexible thinking and behavior, we change what we would normally think or do in response to a new situation, event, or idea.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the flexible thinking Mind Builder as we revisit the book, I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein.
Clifford loves I Am a Cat because it helps him use his flexible thinking skills.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice the flexible thinking Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Simon has told the other cats that he’s a cat, too. Why do you think the big cats laugh at that?
Why do Puma and Panther say Simon can’t be a cat?
Simon is confused. He thought he was a cat, but he learns that he and all the other cats are different from each other.
Would you feel confused if you were Simon? (MB)
Lion says the cats are the same in many ways. They have many things in common.
What do the cats have in common?
The big cats finally change their minds. They say Simon is a cat. What do you think made them change their minds? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use their flexible thinking skills as they play a game of “Simon Says Opposites!” Model play by being Simon and asking children to make a certain movement (e.g., Simon says pat your knees) and then change to say the opposite (e.g., Simon says do not pat your knees). Invite other children to be Simon and offer pairs of opposite instructions.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about animal features.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Flexible thinking involves thinking about something in a different way and taking a different approach to a task or a problem. It plays an important role in problem-solving. Encourage flexible thinking by playing silly rhyming or pun games, inviting children to suggest different uses for everyday objects, or making a new game by changing the rules of a popular game. (Harvard College, 2019)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about a time they needed to listen and remember.
Practice listening and remembering by playing “Follow the Leader.” Challenge children to follow three short directions (e.g., stand up, clap your hands, sit down).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein.
Scout loves I Am a Cat because it’s a narrative that the author made up in her imagination!
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
How are some cats different from others?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on Listening and Remembering
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the picture of Simon and the lion. Does Simon have a mane like Lion does?
Do you think all cats have manes?
Cheetah says cats run faster than all other animals in the world. Do you think Simon can run that fast?
Puma says cats jump high and act tough.
Do you think all cats do those things?
Panther says cats are black. Do you know any cats that are a different color?
Tiger says cats are orange. Do you think all cats are that color? Why or why not?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today?
Let’s see how much you remember as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How are some cats different from others?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Lions have manes, but other cats do not have manes.
Cheetahs can run fast, but many other cats cannot run fast.
Panthers are black, but some cats are not black.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about animal features.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Are cats different colors or the same color?
How are Cheetah and Tiger different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The interactions that happen during back-and-forth communication h elp shape young children’s brains and their social development. The circuits that connect parts of the brain develop at this time. Responsive caregiving and teaching help build an environment for learning, trust, and more!

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion of all they have learned about animals so far this month and this week. What have they learned that they did not know before?
Use the PreK On My Way™ theme music to inspire children to show their best animal moves as they dance to the music.
Introduce two new words that we will use today.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Fantastic Feet. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves informational posters. He can learn so many interesting things!
I Am a Cat and Fantastic Feet both focus on amazing animal features. Let’s see if we find any connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show I Am a Cat book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept questions:
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart and then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can a snail do with its wet, sticky foot?
What do ducks use their feet for?
How are the cat’s claws different from the dog’s claws? When we read I Am a Cat, we learned that cats have sharp claws on their feet.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 20 of I Am a Cat.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do cats use their sharp claws?
How are the gecko’s feet and the snail’s foot alike? How are they different?

section.rac_body-text: With children in a circle, say the name of an animal you have read about this week. Ask a child in the circle to name a feature of that animal. The next child in the circle adds another feature. Model. Continue for three or four features, then name a new animal and have play continue around the circle. Continue until everyone has had at least one turn.
Provide a writing prompt about animal features and give guidance as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making cross-text connections helps all children explore the information contained in a book plus the big ideas carried across texts. Multilingual learners can benefit from frequent access to pictures and other media that cover concepts in the story being read aloud in English.

section-block.rac_body-text: Arrange the class into two groups. Tell children you will say the name of an animal, and Group 1 will call out a feature of that animal. Then Group 2 must say how the animal uses that feature. Model. Give children suggestions, for example, an elephant, a horse, a tiger, a dog, or a bird. After each child has taken a turn, change roles—now Group 1 will be Group 2.
Introduce two new words that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein.
Scout loves this book because it is a narrative about cats. A narrative is a story. Scout loves to read stories!
This week we read all about Simon and other members of his cat family. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
If you were a cat, what feature would you most want to have?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the big book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond to prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lion says a cat’s roar makes everybody tremble.
Why do you think everyone trembles? Can you show me your best tremble?
How do you think Cheetah feels about being faster than any other animal? Show me how fast your feet move when you run.
Puma says cats “leap far, jump high, and act tough.” Do you think Puma has fun when he leaps?
When we go outside, let’s see how far we can leap.
Lion says cats have many features in common, like sharp claws and perky ears. What would you do if you had those features?
How do you think it helps cats to be able to see in the dark?
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
If you were a cat, what feature would you most want to have?
section.rac_body-text: Give some time for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would want a long tail.
I would want to run faster than any other animal.
I would want big eyes that can see in the dark.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about animal features and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you want to have big eyes or sharp claws?
I would want to have sharp cl______ (claws).
I would want to have sharp claws.
What cat features are like features people have?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children become increasingly aware of their bodies, feelings, thoughts, and abilities. They begin to ask, “Who am I?” This awareness is crucial to developing self-control and social skills. Encourage this growing awareness by reading aloud books about self-awareness and by encouraging children’s competence.
